text: I choose to remain silent, gripping the counter tightly as I observe how the situation unfolds.
The drunk’s emotions, however, flare up like oil thrown onto a fire.
He suddenly grabs a bottle and smashes it hard against the floor. Shards and wine scatter everywhere, and the impact forces me to stumble back two steps.
The crowd cries out. The hearth shudders. The stench of alcohol mixed with dust hits me in the face, making me cough.
The drunk’s fist is already raised—
At that very instant, the wind outside roars in, extinguishing half the firelight.
The cloaked woman’s gaze is calm and sharp. With a lift of her hand, both the shards and the wind freeze in midair.
“Enough.”
The drunk stiffens in place, his face turning deathly pale, a hoarse breath rasping from his throat.
His eyes stop on the emblem at the woman’s chest, his pupils suddenly widening.
After a moment of silence, he seems to realize something. His lips tremble, his breathing thrown into disarray.
“You… you’re—”
Before he can finish, it is as if some invisible force strikes him, and he staggers backward.
He turns in panic and practically tumbles out the door in his haste to escape.
The door is slammed shut by the wind with a heavy bang. The tavern sinks back into silence, with only the faint whisper of snow slipping through the cracks.
I remain leaning against the counter, my chest rising unevenly. A shallow cut runs across the back of my hand, the blood gleaming in the firelight.
She glances at me. Her gaze is light as the wind, yet carries a power that is hard to meet directly.
“Next time, be quicker on your feet. You saw the bottle—why didn’t you dodge?”
Her tone is mild as she says it, sounding almost like a reprimand, yet tinged with faint teasing.
I freeze for a moment. Before I can think of a response, she has already walked to the door.
The wind rushes in. She pauses, lifting her hand to gently push the door shut.
“The wind outside has stopped,” she says, turning her head to look at me. “You can catch your breath now.”
She does not leave. Instead, she leans lightly by the door, as if making sure everything has truly ended.
